text: Henry Charles Humphreys (died 1987) was an English-born Papua New Guinean politician. He served as a member of the National Parliament in two spells between 1972 and his death. ==Biography== Humphreys was born in Finchley in Middlesex.Members of the Third House of Assembly, p66 After gaining an intermediate certificate at school, he served in the Territorial Army between 1937 and 1945, before becoming part of the Control Commission in Allied- occupied Germany in 1946. In 1951 he emigrated to the Territory of Papua and New Guinea, where he took on a plantation at Valupai near Talasea in 1953. He became a member of Talasea Local Government Council and West New Britain Advisory Council, as well as serving on the Education and Land boards of West New Britain. He married and had a son. A member of the Pangu Party, he contested the Talasea Open constituency in the 1972 elections and was elected to the House of Assembly, which was renamed the National Parliament at independence in 1975. Although he lost to Gabriel Bakani in the 1977 elections, he returned to defeat Bakani in the 1982 elections.Papua New Guinea Election Results 1972 – 2012 Development Policy Centre He was re-elected in the June–July 1987 elections, but died from a heart attack at Vunapope shortly afterwards.Transitions Pacific Islands Monthly, September 1987, p56 His son Peter later also served as an MP. ==References== Category:People from Finchley Category:British Army personnel of World War II Category:British emigrants to Papua New Guinea Category:Papua New Guinean farmers Category:Members of the House of Assembly of Papua and New Guinea Category:Members of the National Parliament of Papua New Guinea Category:1987 deaths
title: Harry Humphreys
